Comparison with Existed Dataset.
To further demonstrate the data amount of our CLEVR3D, we compare it with two existed datasets, i.e., CLEVR [13] and ScanQA [14].
Table I lists the comparison between CLEVR3D and the most typical VQA-2D dataset, i.e., CLEVR [13], which is similar to our dataset since images in others contain humans and relationships of behaviors.
As shown in the table, CLEVR3D contains a wider range of categories for objects’ attributes, classes, and interrelationships compared with [13].
Furthermore, the comparison with ScanQA [14] is shown in Table II, where our dataset contains 4×4\times questions from 11×11\times scenes.

#question 853,000 41,363 171,174
avg #question 9 52 20

question types 13 6 13
references:
Recent work (ScanQA) [14] also proposes a VQA-3D dataset, however, CLEVR3D is different from ScanQA in the following aspects:
1) Data Generation: They transform question-answer pairs from the descriptions in the ScanRefer dataset [6] through a T5-base model [15].
Our dataset is generated based on 3D semantic scene graphs, where more attributes for objects (e.g., material) and question types (e.g., existence) are provided, as shown in Table II.
2) Data Scale:
Their generation strategy greatly depends on the number of descriptions in the ScanRefer dataset.
In contrast, we gain theoretically unlimited question-answer pairs through augmenting the scene graph.
In practice, CLEVR3D contains 4×4\times questions from 11×11\times scenes.
3) Scenario: They only focus on VQA-3D in real-world scenes, while we also tackle the problem in simulated common-sense-independent scenes.

Comparison with Existed Dataset.
To further demonstrate the data amount of our CLEVR3D, we compare it with two existed datasets, i.e., CLEVR [13] and ScanQA [14].
Table I lists the comparison between CLEVR3D and the most typical VQA-2D dataset, i.e., CLEVR [13], which is similar to our dataset since images in others contain humans and relationships of behaviors.
As shown in the table, CLEVR3D contains a wider range of categories for objects’ attributes, classes, and interrelationships compared with [13].
Furthermore, the comparison with ScanQA [14] is shown in Table II, where our dataset contains 4×4\times questions from 11×11\times scenes.

Baselines.
To evaluate the VQA-3D task, we introduce several baselines, including
pure language models, vision-language cross-modal models and humans results.
Table III demonstrates the comparison results among these methods.

Comparison.
We adopt Accuracy as the evaluation metric and present the results of different question types on the CLEVR3D-REAL dataset are shown in Table III.
TransVQA3D achieves the best result almost in all question categories, significantly surpassing the pure language model.
It should be noted that utilizing the feature fusion in ReferIt3D [7] cannot effectively improve the VQA-3D performance.
Without the well-designed architecture and scene graph aware feature enhancement, the performance of ScanQA [14] is significantly lower than ours.
Notably, there still exists a gap over the human responses, especially for “count” and “query object”.
Some demos of TransVQA3D for VQA-3D are visualized in Fig. 8.
Moreover, CLEVR3D-SIM can effectively boost the performance of the model in real-world VQA-3D, as shown in Table III. We also illustrate the results directly training and testing on CLEVR3D-SIM in Table IV.
Note that the results on CLEVR3D-SIM is higher than that on CLEVR3D-REAL since the data amount on the former is much larger.

S5.T5.caption: TABLE V: Scene graph analysis on 3DSSG dataset. Top-K Recall is utilized as the evaluation metric. We compare different methods on node classification, predicate classification, and relationship triplet.
S5.T5.table:
Method Object Classification Predicate Classification Relationships Triplet
R@5 R@10 R@3 R@5 R@50 R@100
SGPN [10] 66.2 77.5 62.5 88.8 39.2 45.5
3DSSG [10] 68.0 78.1 89.0 93.4 40.9 66.8
SceneGraphFusion [12] 70.0 80.0 97.0 99.0 85.0 87.0
TransVQA3D w/o VQA-3D 69.2 79.1 97.3 99.5 86.8 88.5
TransVQA3D 71.8 80.6 98.0 99.8 87.1 89.8
references:
To further validate the effectiveness of our proposed methods on 3D scene understanding, we evaluate TransVQA3D for scene graph analysis on the 3DSSG dataset [10].
We follow the experimental settings of [10], including the train/test split and corresponding semantics.
We evaluate the model on 160 object and 26 predicate classes with [10] in Table V.
Its vanilla model (i.e., SGPN in the table) uses two PointNets [45] to extract the features of the object and relationship, respectively.
Upon this baseline, it further adopts the GCN to conduct feature aggregation between nodes (i.e., 3DSSG).
It separately evaluates the predicate (relationship) prediction in isolation from the object classes, where we adopt the Top-k Recall score [57] as the metric.
Moreover, the performances of the object categories are reported.
We further evaluate the most confident (subject, predicate, object) triplets against the ground truth in a top-k recall manner.
As illustrated in Table V, our model effectively improves scene graph analysis in all scene graph-related metrics, especially for relationships triplet.

S5.T6.caption: TABLE VI: Ablation studies for multitask learning of VQA-3D and scene graph analysis. The upper, middle, and lower parts demonstrate the effectiveness of exploiting multitask, different designs for SGAA module and Cross-modal Transformer, respectively.
S5.T6.table:
Model Task CMT SGAA SG Analysis VQA-3D
NumLayer PE TA CMA Node (R@5) Edge (R@5) Overall ClassAvg
A VQA-3D 3 ✓ - - - - 39.7 40.1
B VQA-3D+Node 3 ✓ - - 68.3 - 42.7 45.6
C Node+Edge 3 ✓ ✓ ✓ 66.7 94.7 - -
D VQA-3D+Node+Edge 3 ✓ ✓ ✓ 71.8 99.8 45.5 50.9
E VQA-3D+Node+Edge 3 ✓ ✗ ✓ 67.9 65.3 42.5 44.3
F VQA-3D+Node+Edge 3 ✓ ✓ ✗ 71.4 99.5 43.7 47.5
G VQA-3D+Node+Edge 4 ✓ ✓ ✓ 70.2 97.6 44.5 47.4
H VQA-3D+Node+Edge 2 ✓ ✓ ✓ 68.5 95.8 43.2 45.1
I VQA-3D+Node+Edge 3 ✗ ✓ ✓ 67.1 94.5 42.1 44.9
references:
We conduct ablation studies on different designs of our architecture in Table VI.
In the upper part (models A-D), we demonstrate the mutual enhancement between VQA-3D and scene graph reasoning.
In the middle part (models E and F), we explore different designs of the SGAA module.
In the lower part (models G-I), we present the results of using different Cross-modal Transformer (CMT) designs.
Apart from the metric of Overall Accuracy (Overall), we also report the results of Class Average Accuracy (ClassAvg) to measure the abilities of models crossing different question types.

Does scene graph analysis help VQA-3D?
We provide the results of only exploiting VQA-3D task in model A, where we do not apply object (node) classification and edge (predicate) prediction.
In Table VI, it is evident that model A gains a low overall accuracy of 39.7 for VQA-3D.
When we apply additional supervision of object classification (model B) during the training, the Overall boosts from 39.7 to 42.7, which implies the significance of the object classification.
Besides, scene graph prediction also help improve the VQA-3D results (model D).
There is a noticeable improvement in the absolute accuracy by 2% when utilizing the SGAA module for edge prediction.

Does VQA-3D help scene graph analysis?
We show the ablated results by discarding the language branch and answer prediction head during the training.
As shown in Table VI (model C), only conducting scene graph reasoning leads to an obvious degradation on both node and edge prediction (about 5%).
